Introduction.Definition: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language for creating web pages and web applications.
Introduction.History: HTML was created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991 and has since evolved through multiple versions, with HTML5 being the latest major release.
Features: Defines the structure of web pages
Uses elements and tags to organize content
Supports multimedia elements like images, videos, and audio
Works seamlessly with CSS and JavaScript

HowItWorks.Structure: HTML documents are structured using nested elements enclosed within angle brackets <>.
HowItWorks.Rendering: Browsers interpret HTML code and render it as a visual webpage.
HowItWorks.Syntax: HTML uses opening and closing tags to define elements.

Usage.WhyUseIt: HTML is the foundation of web development, providing the basic structure and content of web pages.
HowItIsUsed: Working with forms for user input
Serving as the base for CSS and JavaScript to enhance interactivity

Elements.Definition: HTML elements are the building blocks of a web page, defined by tags.

Attributes.Definition: Attributes provide additional information about elements.

Headings.Definition: HTML provides six levels of headings, from <h1> (largest) to <h6> (smallest).

Paragraphs.Definition:
The

tag defines paragraphs of text.

Lists.Definition: Lists are used to display items in an ordered or unordered format.

Links.Definition: Links (<a>) are used to navigate between web pages.

Images.Definition: The tag is used to embed images in a webpage.

Forms.Definition: Forms collect user input through text fields, checkboxes, radio buttons, and more.

Tables.Definition: HTML tables display data in rows and columns.
